entry.title: Re: General Ledger Report not showing Dimensions data
entry.content:
Hi Carmen,

Just to exclude possible culprits, run the query below, replacing <your journal ID> with an actual journal entry id. Check whether the cost allocation fields contain any data. If they do, it might be something else related to the SAP UI.

SELECT 
    TransId AS 'Journal Entry ID'
    , RefDate AS 'Posting Date'
    , ProfitCode AS 'Cost Center 1'
    , OcrCode2 AS 'Cost Center 2'
    , OcrCode3 AS 'Cost Center 3'
    , OcrCode4 AS 'Cost Center 4'
    , OcrCode5 AS 'Cost Center 5'
FROM JDT1
WHERE TransId = <your journal ID>

Also, have a look at SAP's documentation and see if there is something out of place there: General Settings: Cost Accounting Tab | SAP Help Portal

I hope it helps.

BR,
Felipe

entry.title: Enabling AD -based Kerberos for Windows, MacBook, and Desktop Linux
entry.content:
Intro and context

Many organisations use Kerberos workflows based on Microsoft Active Directory for handling SSO for browser-based (HTTP, HTTPS) applications.

These Kerberos workflows require various configuration activities like setting up the Kerberos server, configuring systems that should be able to accept Kerberos token requests to logon, and so on... this blog assumes that on the server-side everything is configured correctly, so that e.g. Kerberos is known to be already working, or has previously been working. Our scope will be advice on configuring the client-side computers and their browsers; for example, in case some OS+Browser combination isn't already working, you might find the blog's advice useful.

We give solutions for three OS-paradigms: for Windows 11; for Apple macOS (i.e. MacBooks); and for Xubuntu Desktop (Linux).  Scroll down to the OS you are interested in.

Then there are two Appendices - Appendix A: Other browser properties gives some info about two other browser properties that may need to be configured (they weren't relevant for my environment, therefore not implemented by me); Appendix B: SAP Secure Login Client shows how to manually get the Kerberos token for SAP Secure Login Client (on Windows) .

Disclaimer: Think of this blog as "Tips and Tricks" on client side of Kerberos config. Really, I cannot provide debug help to any readers - instead, just wishing yous all good luck fixing your own specific cases and configurations using your own debug-n-configure skills! üëç

 

Windows 11 - general remarks

An indication that the client-side config needs improving can be that when you try to logon to some website on your intranet, you are prompted in Edge or Chrome to first supply your AD logon credentials manually, e.g.:

In Firefox, you might be directed instead straight to the manual logon page of the website itself.

So we want to fix these situations, by configuration. The Edge and Chrome browsers have similar configuration steps, as they are both based on Chromium. Firefox has a different way to handle Kerberos config.

 

Windows Settings app (Edge, Chrome)

Open Settings app, go to Network & internet -> Advanced network settings -> Internet options ... the Internet Properties dialog should open, go to Security tab and select Local intranet:

From there, click on Sites -> Advanced, then add the websites of interest... there are 2 ways you could do this addition - first way is to specify each website (protocol + hostname), for example:

http://nw-portal.example.com

https://sap-solman.example.com

...and so on, accumulating items as you discover the websites where AD-based SSO should work.

Another way is to generalise using wildcards, and also we can generalise by not specifying a protocol - i.e. we cover both the HTTP and the HTTPS cases, and can get away with a one-line addition... e.g. if all our relevant websites are subdomains of example.com then:

*.example.com

[Note that if your main domain, example.com for uhh, example... if it also offers authentication of SSO requests, then you would likely add "example.com" as an extra item, since it isn't covered by "*.example.com" due to the dot after the wildcard].

Anyway then we can close the windows (Close -> OK) to get back to Internet Properties window, and then for Security->Local intranet, we click on Custom level... scroll down to User Authentication and make sure Logon radiobutton "Automatic logon only in Intranet zone" is on. Then OK to close the window. Then switch to Advanced tab and scroll down to Security section and make sure "Enable Integrated Windows Authentication" is on. Then OK to close the Internet Properties.

If you close then reopen Edge and Chrome, they will now be able to use the computer's Kerberos TGT (ticket granting ticket) to authenticate to the named server/protocol combinations.

It might be that the option to Add websites in the Local intranet -> Sites dialog box, is greyed out with a message saying that this setting is managed by your organisation's System Administrators. If so, you could ask your admins to rollout a policy that includes the needed websites; or you can check out the other solutions in this blog.

 

Windows HKLM Registry approach (Edge, Chrome)

For this approach, you need to have local administrator rights to your computer. Two ways to make the changes are now described, before that though: close Edge and Chrome completely (check and take action in Task Manager if needed).

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/deployedge/microsoft-edge-browser-policies/authserverallowlist

The first way, is to open a Command Prompt in Run as Administrator mode, then run the following two commands, replacing "*.example.com,example.com" with the list relevant to your own organisation - you can specify actual servers and/or use wildcards:

reg add HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Policies\Microsoft\Edge /v AuthServerAllowlist /t REG_SZ /d *example.com,example.com /reg:64 /f

reg add HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Policies\Google\Chrome /v AuthServerAllowlist /t REG_SZ /d *example.com,example.com /reg:64 /f

Then restart Edge and Chrome, and check the policy has been picked up by entering the relevant URL for each browser:

edge://policy

or

chrome://policy

 

Now you should be able to logon to the websites that use AD-based Kerberos for SSO logon (assuming of course that the Kerberos configurations on the server-side are correct).

The other way to do this config, is to open the app called 'regedit' (Registry Editor) and from there implement the same stuff as specified in the commands given above or relying on the Microsoft advice in the link above. Leaving that as an exercise for the reader.

See Appendix A: Other browser properties for other properties of Edge and Chrome that may also be relevant to configure.

 

Windows - and MacBook - using Firefox

If you do not have the rights to implement solutions for Edge and Chrome, or if you just prefer using Mozilla Firefox, then this solution might be useful...

Open Firefox and enter the URL:

about:config

Click past the warning message. Search for the key:

network.negotiate-auth.trusted-uris

Enter some relevant value - you can enter a comma-separated list, or a generic wildcard value (no asterisk needed though), for example:

nw-portal.example.com,sap-solman.example.com

or:

example.com

Hit <Enter> to save your changes. And that is all that should be needed. Now you can SSO into those websites that are accepting AD-based Kerberos logons.

[Be aware that to SSO into a second website using a different authentication server, probably you will need to create a new Firefox session e.g. a guest session, so that Firefox doesn't offer the second server an (invalid, in the second server's opinion) token from the first server].

See Appendix A: Other browser properties for a second Firefox property that can sometimes be relevant for about:config activity.

 

MacBook using Firefox

The configuration steps are exactly the same as for Firefox on Windows, so refer to previous section above "Windows - and MacBook - using Firefox".

By implementing this solution, you would typically be replacing the original authentication failure - HTTP 401 Unauthorised, returned because the website received no AD-based Kerberos credentials - resulting in the website falling back to asking for a manual logon:

...so thanks to our minor config change, we replaced those HTTP 401s with successful SSO logons to the website using AD-based Kerberos, .

See Appendix A: Other browser properties for a second Firefox property that can sometimes be relevant for about:config activity.

 

MacBook using Safari

So far, this combination has always worked out of the box for me in various work environments, so I don't have any advice on how to configure Safari for AD-based Kerberos logins, as never had any need to investigate that. Anyway it seems that Safari relies on Apple's Kerberos SSO Extension implementation:

https://support.apple.com/en-gb/guide/deployment/depe6a1cda64/web

FYR: on MacBook you can view your AD-logon details using the app called "Ticket Viewer", or in Terminal you can run the commands:

klist

klist -v

...to see information e.g. about e.g. the krbtgt (Kerberos Ticket Granting Ticket).

 

MacBook using Chrome and Edge

The solution is quite easy (though like most things that look easy, finding the solution wasn't that easy).

Close Chrome and Edge. Open the Terminal app, and run the following commands, replacing "*.example.com,example.com" with the relevant list of servers and/or wildcard entries that fit your own organisation's needs best:

defaults write com.google.Chrome AuthServerAllowlist "*.example.com,example.com"

defaults write com.microsoft.Edge AuthServerAllowlist "*.example.com,example.com"

These commands add an entry to the respective plist files:

~/Library/Preferences/com.google.Chrome.plist 

~/Library/Preferences/com.microsoft.Edge.plist

(Xcode is the best app for viewing those plist files).

Anyway now you can re-open Chrome and Edge, and if you like you can check that the relevant policy was uploaded by the browser using the relevant URL:

chrome://policy

edge://policy

Now your AD-based Kerberos SSO into relevant websites should work fine. See (below) Appendix A: Other browser properties in case similar work needs to be done for those other properties.

[You can use Guest sessions, or switching between Chrome personas, if you want to access multiple different websites while avoiding the trap where the first website's tokens are offered to the second website for that second website to reject them :)].

 

Xubuntu and Kerberos

Xubuntu Desktop distro is a popular variant of Ubuntu Desktop (difference is only in the Desktop Manager - actually I obtained the Xubuntu Desktop by installing arm64 Ubuntu Server, and then installing the Xubuntu packages).

First we need to set up the client machine's Kerberos functionality:

https://documentation.ubuntu.com/server/how-to/kerberos/basic-workstation-authentication/

sudo apt install krb5-user sssd-krb5

We give the "realm" (which in my case is the hostname of the Kerberos server), and hit <Enter>

For us, it is enough to be able to obtain a Kerberos ticket "on demand", so we skip the sssd-configuration and instead just test the 'kinit' utility:

kinit <ADUSER>@<Kerberos.server>

Then check if the krbtgt (Kerberos Ticket Granting Ticket) was obtained:

klist

We probably also need to specify explicitly, in the main Kerberos config file, where the Ticket cache is (filepath and syntax visible via 'klist' in above screenshot)... so let's do that:

sudo nano /etc/krb5.conf

Add the relevant value, here is an example:

default_ccache_name = FILE:/tmp/krb5cc_1000

Ctrl+O, Ctrl+X to save and exit from the editor.

 

Xubuntu Chromium

We can use the advice from this Ask Ubuntu thread:

https://askubuntu.com/questions/1204571/how-to-install-chromium-without-snap

sudo add-apt-repository ppa:xtradeb/apps -y

sudo apt update

sudo apt install chromium

[Yes that is Chromium, not Chrome... as of September 2025 when doing these POCs, no arm64 Chrome for Ubuntu-family desktop distros available... so we take Chromium, which is the upstream browser project from which Chrome (and Edge) are derived].

If like me you are running this Linux distro as a VM that is not pre-configured by your organisation, then you may want to export your organisation's CA and Root CA .pem files (e.g. in the host machine, go to some intranet website and export the certificates from there), and then import them into your Linux Chromium browser, from here:

chrome://certificate-manager/localcerts

Result of your imports should show up in "Installed by you" section of the settings...

[For non-GUI-browser situations, e.g. when using curl or wget, there is a different solution for importing the certificates to the Ubuntu filesystem, but that is outside the scope of this blog].

Anyway we can then start up Chromium from the command line supplying the temporary list of Authenticating-by-Kerberos servers, as a comma-separated list and with relevant wildcard use according to your needs:

chromium --auth-server-allowlist="*.example.com,example.com"

So this should work (try Refresh in case the first time the browser uses some previously cached "manual login" page). But it would be better to implement a solution that doesn't require the user to specify options from the command line each time they open Chromium, so here is the more permanent solution... I used these pages of advice, note that there are Ubuntu-specific and Chromium-specific paths involved...

https://support.google.com/chrome/a/answer/9027408?hl=en

https://www.chromium.org/administrators/linux-quick-start/

For this example we will use the managed_policies.json file i.e. make the new policy mandatory for users...

sudo mkdir -p /etc/chromium/policies/managed

cd /etc/chromium/policies/managed

sudo touch managed_policies.json

sudo pico managed_policies.json

Add the policy:

{
    "AuthServerAllowlist": "*.example.com,example.com"
}

Ctrl-O, Ctrl-X to save and exit from the pico-editor.

Now we can start Chromium up e.g. from the GUI Menu, under category Internet, and check that the new policy was loaded by going to

chrome://policy

 

Now our SSO via AD-based Kerberos works fine. Note that to switch from one SSO over AD-Kerberos workflow to one provided by another server, you may need to close Chromium then re-open it.

See Appendix A: Other browser properties for other properties of Chromium that may also be relevant to configure. 

 

Xubuntu Firefox... the right kind of Firefox

Recent editions (e.g. 24.04 LTS) of Ubuntu Desktop are delivered with the so-called "snap"-package variant of Firefox already installed; however I found that this "snap"-Firefox doesn't work with Kerberos, not for me anyway. So instead, we should get rid of "snap"-Firefox and replace it with "apt-repo"-Firefox. Here is the advice I used:

https://askubuntu.com/questions/1399383/how-to-install-firefox-as-a-traditional-deb-package-without-snap-in-ubuntu-22

"[...]

sudo add-apt-repository ppa:mozillateam/ppa

Then, copy and paste the following code in a terminal in one go (don't copy-paste line by line) to prioritize the apt version of firefox over the snap version.

echo '
Package: *
Pin: release o=LP-PPA-mozillateam
Pin-Priority: 1001

Package: firefox
Pin: version 1:1snap*
Pin-Priority: -1
' | sudo tee /etc/apt/preferences.d/mozilla-firefox

Next, remove the snap version of firefox

sudo snap remove firefox

[...]

Install Firefox with apt.

sudo apt install firefox

[...]"

Ok good - note that now we cannot open Firefox as default Web Browser directly from top-level GUI menu (as "Web Browser" refers to deleted snap-version); instead we can use the GUI category "Internet" (Chromium is also listed under this category) and open our new Firefox item there... or type "fire" in the menu search bar and choose Firefox... or we can start the new Firefox from command line:

firefox

Then we should import any needed CA certificates of the organisation...  from the "I-ching" icon in top-right of Firefox menu bars, choose Settings, then type "cert" so that "View Certificates" option comes up:

Open the View Certificates dialog and choose Import.. and then, well, import the needed certificates. Once done, those are visible in View Certificates (scroll through list till you see them).

Now we are at the stage where we can do the same procedure as with Firefox on other OSes above...enter the URL:

about:config

Click past the warning message. Search for the key:

network.negotiate-auth.trusted-uris

Enter some relevant value - you can enter a comma-separated list, or a generic wildcard value (no asterisk needed though), for example:

nw-portal.example.com,sap-solman.example.com

or:

example.com

Hit <Enter> to save your changes. And that is all that should be needed. Now you can SSO into those websites that are accepting AD-based Kerberos logons.

 

See Appendix A: Other browser properties for a second Firefox property that can sometimes be relevant for about:config activity.

 

Appendix A: Other browser properties

FYR: in case your Kerberos setup involves credential-delegation servers, and/or in case you need to specify an Authentication Scheme in e.g. Edge (cases I have no actual experience with) then the following Keys and their values may be of interest:

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/deployedge/microsoft-edge-browser-policies/authnegotiatedelegateallowlist

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/deployedge/microsoft-edge-browser-policies/authschemes

[These links are about Edge, but in practice Edge, Chrome, and Chromium are a family - Edge and Chrome based on Chromium - so there are many properties that are identical by name and function].

Chrome, Edge:

AuthNegotiateDelegateAllowlist

AuthSchemes

Firefox equivalent of AuthNegotiateDelegateAllowlist (via about:config we can modify this key):

network.negotiate-auth.delegation-uris

... The AuthNegotiateDelegateAllowlist Keys (and Firefox equivalent) would have as value typically some hostname such as:

authserver.example.com

If your organisation is using other paradigms for authentication such as NTLM, then you might need or want to specify the AuthSchemes Key with the relevant schemes as values in comma-separated form, for example with Kerberos and NTLM you would have:

negotiate,ntlm

 

Appendix B: SAP Secure Login Client

Although this blog is focused on browsers, we note that SAP Secure Login Client can also use AD-based Kerberos tokens for SAPGUI SSO. Normally, the Secure Login Client obtains the needed Kerberos token from the user's cache... however, we had a situation during initial testing of Windows 11, where for some reason this automatic retrieval of Kerberos token was not working for a while. So, in such cases, here is a possible (though not very elegant or scalable) workaround...

In the Windows In-Tray -> click on the wee icon with a white tick-mark on a blue diamond background (SAP Secure Login Client):

Double-click on the relevant item that says ‚ÄúKerberos Token‚Äù:

Enter your AD-credentials and click ‚ÄúOK‚Äù:

Assuming the AD logon succeeds, now your AD-based Kerberos SSO logons to SAP systems via SAPGUI sessions should work again, as SAP Secure Login Client has the Kerberos token it needs.

entry.title: Synchronous Goods Receipt
entry.content:
Hello,

SAP Support recently advised me to enable Synchronous Goods Receipt to resolve an issue. I would appreciate clarification on the correct configuration steps and potential implications.

From the SAP documentation & blogs, it appears the change involves updating the value from Post Synchronous to Bin to Goods Receipt and Goods Issue. My questions are:

  1. Is this the only required change, or are there additional settings needed in eWM?

  2. How does the WM Request field factor into this configuration?

  3. Beyond eliminating the need for an Inbound Delivery, are there other functional or process consequences I should be aware of?

System details:

  • SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud 2508

  • Embedded WM (not Distributed)

  • Production Orders

I am the sole SAP resource at my company and relatively new to eWM, so I want to ensure I fully understand the scope and impact before implementing this change.

Thank you for your guidance.

Vicki

entry.title: Re: Advanced Intercompany Sales - Copy Condition between...
entry.content:
By standard configuration alone, it is not possible to copy the IC SO condition type value into PO condition PB00. This is taking into consideration, the standard configuration behavior is

  • PB00 in PO is determined by the MM pricing procedure assigned to the purchasing document type.
  • The IC SO conditions (e.g. PR00, Zxxx) are determined by the SD pricing procedure.
  • There is no standard config switch to ‚Äúcopy‚Äù condition values directly from the IC SO into the PO.

Some options are

  • Maintain the same condition records for intercompany sales and intercompany purchasing. Ensure PB00 in PO and PR00 (or equivalent) in SO are aligned via condition records.
  • If you want PB00 to always equal the IC SO condition, a custom requirement/formula routine / user exit can be written and assigned in the PO pricing procedure.

entry.title: Re: Notification in SVT when registration data is not mai...
entry.content:
Hello

your demand can be solved in SAP standard without a problem; but as mentioned: people do not love the mail notification existing.

IN a nutshell: read the online help of substance tracking; try to understadn the topic of "online check" and "eMail" generation and then just implement and deploy.

From experience: it is a very bad decision to start like your planning that. Normally the business knows what objects are relevant for "REACH"; and Reach is clear: no registration, no market.

But SVT is only working as required if the business do have the "full control" regarding data maintenance etc.

And the business need a good understanding, what need to be done if data is missing to get rid of the emails.

The REACH part is true for: Imports, Production; but the set up depends on the fact: do you use an "OR" or not. Do you have company codes outsid of REACH area delivering to REACH area?

This i as well, from legal point of view, an import but ony allowed if either the "receiver" is acting as an "importer" or you use the "OR model

Wish you the best

C.B.

entry.title: The Importance of Cross-Module Knowledge for SAP Consultants
entry.content:
The Importance of Cross-Module Knowledge for SAP Consultants

In today‚Äôs dynamic SAP landscape, being a consultant means much more than mastering your own module. As a functional consultant in SAP MM, I‚Äôve learned over the years that success in real projects often depends on how well you understand the integration points with other modules.

   Why Cross-Module Knowledge Matters

End-to-End Processes: Business processes rarely stop at one module. A purchase order in MM eventually impacts FI through accounting entries, SD when linked to sales, and PP when it involves production. Without cross-module awareness, consultants risk missing critical dependencies.

Better Communication with Teams: Projects bring together FI, SD, PP, WM, and other consultants. Knowing their language and challenges helps avoid misunderstandings and ensures smoother collaboration.

Problem-Solving: Many issues reported by end users appear to be ‚ÄúMM problems,‚Äù but in reality, they stem from integration‚Äîsuch as GR/IR mismatches (MM‚ÄìFI), stock discrepancies (MM‚ÄìWM), or subcontracting issues (MM‚ÄìPP). A consultant with cross-module knowledge can resolve issues faster.

   Key Integration Areas for MM Consultants

MM‚ÄìFI: Inventory valuation, account determination, invoice verification.

MM‚ÄìSD: Third-party order processing, intercompany stock transfers.

MM‚ÄìPP: Material requirements planning, subcontracting, and production orders.

MM‚ÄìWM/EWM: Goods receipt, stock placement, and picking processes.

    Benefits for Your Career

Stronger Profile: Recruiters and clients look for consultants who can think beyond one module.

Added Value: You become a bridge between teams, often reducing delays in projects.

Future-Readiness: In SAP S/4HANA, processes are even more integrated, making cross-module knowledge a must-have skill.

    How to Build Cross-Module Skills

Learn from your colleagues on projects‚Äîask questions, join design workshops.

Explore integration scenarios in a training or sandbox system.

Follow SAP documentation and blogs focused on cross-functional processes.

Share knowledge within your teams and communities to reinforce your learning.

 

Final Thought: Mastering your own module is essential, but expanding into cross-module knowledge transforms you from a ‚Äúconsultant‚Äù into a true process expert. In the end, it‚Äôs not just about configuring SAP,it‚Äôs about understanding and optimizing business processes end to end.

entry.title: Re: HOW TO SELECT BUSINESS GROUPING FOR SUPPLIER AND CUST...
entry.content:
In S/4HANA Public Cloud (2508), you don‚Äôt create your own BP groupings ‚Äî you must use the pre-delivered ones. The most common are:

For Customers

  • If you want a full customer (sold-to) ‚Üí use BP01.
  • If you need additional partner functions (ship-to, bill-to, payer), you can load them separately with BP02, BPAB, BP03.
  • In most projects, BP01 is sufficient for the main customer master.

For Suppliers

  • If the supplier is only for accounting (no purchasing) ‚Üí use CPDA.
  • If the supplier is only for purchasing (no FI posting) ‚Üí use CPDN.
  • If the supplier is both purchasing + accounting (the majority of cases) ‚Üí use CPDS.

Most importantly, do not fill the ‚ÄúCustomer Account Group‚Äù or ‚ÄúVendor Account Group‚Äù fields in the migration template. The system derives them automatically from the Grouping you select. If you fill them, you‚Äôll get errors like ‚ÄúAssignment of BP grouping XXXX to account group not possible‚Äù. Always check the migration object documentation in the Migration Cockpit for the release you‚Äôre on, as SAP sometimes adjusts which groupings are available. In Public Cloud, you cannot create your own BP groupings ‚Äî you must use the delivered ones.

entry.title: The Ultimate SAP S/4HANA Master Data Guide & Test Plan
entry.content:
The Ultimate SAP S/4HANA Master Data Guide & Test Plan

Introduction

  • Welcome to your all-in-one guide to mastering key logistical and financial master data objects in SAP S/4HANA. This document is designed for a wide audience‚Äîfrom end-users performing daily tasks to key users training their teams, and consultants implementing the system. We will transform complex test scripts into a logical, end-to-end process flow, focusing on practical application and understanding the "why" behind the "how."
  • This guide prioritizes the modern SAP Fiori user experience but will refer to SAP GUI transactions where they remain relevant. Each chapter is a self-contained module that serves as both a learning guide and a hands-on test plan, complete with real-world scenarios to practice.
  • Let's begin your journey to becoming an SAP S/4HANA master data expert!

Chapter 1: Managing Product Substitutions & Exclusions (Scope Item 4VO)

  • This chapter focuses on a critical sales and distribution function: automatically substituting or excluding products during order entry. This is essential for managing product lifecycles, handling stock-outs gracefully, and ensuring customers receive appropriate items.

1.1. Core Concepts: What are Product Substitution and Exclusion?

  • In any business, products evolve. An older model is replaced by a new one, a product is discontinued, or perhaps a deluxe version is offered when the standard is out of stock. Manually managing these changes in every single sales order is inefficient and prone to error. SAP's Product Substitution and Exclusion functionality automates this.
  • Product Substitution: This technique allows the system to automatically replace one product with another during sales order creation. This is useful for various reasons, such as when a product is out of stock or has been replaced by a newer version. For example, if a customer orders an iPhone 16 but it's out of stock, the system could suggest an iPhone 16 Pro as a substitute.
  • Product Exclusion: This prevents a specific product from being offered as a substitute. This is typically used for items that are discontinued and have no direct replacement.

1.2. Prerequisites & Configuration Insights

  • Before you can create substitution records, certain foundational elements must be in place.

Required Roles and Access:

  • Business Role: Master Data Specialist - Product Data (ID: SAP_BR_PRODMASTER_SPECIALIST).
  • System Access: You'll need access to the SAP Fiori Launchpad.

Mandatory Master Data:

  • You must have at least two existing material/product master records in the system: one to be substituted and one to act as the substitute. These are typically created using the
  • Create Product Master (BNF) script or the Manage Product Master Data Fiori app.

Configuration Deep Dive (For Consultants & Key Users):

  • While the preliminary steps of creating
  • Reasons, Groups, and Controls for substitution are listed as optional in the process, they are powerful configuration tools for managing complex substitution logic. These are configured through specific Fiori apps:
  • Manage Substitution Reasons - Products (F4789): Here, you define
  • why a substitution is occurring (e.g., 'UPGRADE', 'STOCKOUT'). This adds clarity for reporting and analysis.
  • Manage Substitution Groups - Products (F4788): Groups allow you to bundle products together for substitution purposes. For example, you could create a group called 'STANDARD_MONITORS'.
  • Manage Substitution Controls - Products (F4787) : Controls define the rules and context for substitution, such as applying them only for 'SALES' scenarios.
  • These settings provide the backbone for a robust and scalable substitution strategy. For a simple substitution, they are not mandatory, but for an enterprise-wide implementation, they are highly recommended.

1.3. Practical Exercise & Test Plan: Creating a Product Substitution

  • Let's walk through a real-world scenario.
  • Scenario: Our company, Global Electronics, is phasing out the TG-MONITOR-24 (a 24-inch trading good monitor) and replacing it with the new, improved TG-MONITOR-25. We need to ensure that any sales orders for the old monitor automatically propose the new one.

Part 1: (Optional) Create a Substitution Reason

  1. Log In: Access the SAP Fiori launchpad as a Master Data Specialist - Product Data.
  2. Access the App: Open the Fiori app Manage Substitution Reasons - Products (F4789).
  3. Create New Reason:
    • Click the
  • Create button.
    • In the
  • Reason field, enter UPG_01.
    • Click
  • Create to save the header.
  1. Add Description:
    • In the "Description" section that now appears, click
  • Create.
    • Enter
  • Language Key: EN.
    • Enter
  • Reason Description: Product Upgrade/Replacement.
    • Click
  • Create to save the description. You should see a success message.

Part 2: Create the Product Substitution Record

  • This is the core procedure where we link the old product to the new one.
  1. Access the App: From the Fiori Launchpad, open the Manage Substitutions - Products (F4785) app.
  2. Initiate Creation: Click the Create button to start a new substitution record.
  3. Enter Header Data: This is the most critical step.
    • Product: Enter TG-MONITOR-24 (the product being replaced).
    • Substitute Product: Enter TG-MONITOR-25 (the new product).
    • Plant: You can leave this blank for a global substitution or enter a specific plant (e.g., 1710) to make the rule plant-specific. For our scenario, let's leave it blank.
    • Note: The Product and Substitute Product fields are mandatory.
  4. Enter General Information (Optional):
    • Reason: Select the reason we created earlier, UPG_01 (Product Upgrade/Replacement).
    • Valid From Date: Enter today's date to make the substitution effective immediately.
    • Leave the
  • Valid To Date blank to make the substitution valid indefinitely.
  1. Save and Activate:
    • Click Create at the bottom of the screen to save the draft record. You will receive a success message.
    • The system will return you to the main screen for your new record. Crucially, you must now click
  • Set to Active to make the rule effective. Another success message will confirm it is active.

Test Execution & Expected Results:

  • Test: A Sales Representative creates a new sales order using the Create Sales Orders (VA01) app. They enter the old material TG-MONITOR-24 and a quantity.
  • Expected Result: Upon pressing Enter, a pop-up screen should appear, informing the user that the product has been substituted. The pop-up will show the original product (TG-MONITOR-24) and the substitute product (TG-MONITOR-25). The user can then select the substitute to replace the original item in the sales order. The substitution has worked successfully.

Chapter 2: Creating Master Recipes for Process Industries (3X9)

  • This chapter is for businesses in process industries (e.g., chemicals, pharmaceuticals, food and beverage) that use batch-oriented manufacturing. The Master Recipe is the cornerstone of production planning and execution in this environment.

2.1. Core Concepts: What is a Master Recipe?

  • Unlike a standard routing used in discrete manufacturing, a Master Recipe describes a non-continuous production process. It's a template for manufacturing a product, detailing the steps, resources, materials, and quality checks required.
  • Key components of a Master Recipe include:
  • Operations: Major steps in the production process (e.g., Mixing, Heating, Bottling).
  • Phases: Detailed activities within an operation. A phase is where work is actually performed, resources are consumed, and standard values (like machine time and labor time) are recorded.
  • Resources: The work centers (machines, labor, production lines) where phases are carried out.
  • Material Assignments: Links the components from the Bill of Material (BOM) to the specific phase where they are consumed.
  • The Master Recipe is the direct input for creating
  • Process Orders and is fundamental for Product Costing.

2.2. Prerequisites & Configuration Insights

Required Roles and Access:

  • Business Role: Production Engineer - Process Manufacturing (ID: SAP_BR_PRODN_ENG_PROC).
  • System Access: SAP Fiori Launchpad.

Mandatory Master Data:

  • Product Master: You need material masters for the finished/semi-finished good being produced, as well as for all raw material components.
  • Resource: At least one resource (work center) must exist where the operations will be performed.
  • Bill of Material (BOM): An optional but highly recommended prerequisite. Having a BOM allows you to directly assign material components to the recipe steps.

Configuration Deep Dive (For Consultants & Key Users):

  • Transaction/App: The primary Fiori app is Manage Master Recipes (F5426). The corresponding GUI transaction is
  • C201 (Create) / C202 (Change).
  • Profile (YPI1): The profile used when creating a recipe is a key configuration point. It presets default values, field selections, and the overall screen sequence, streamlining data entry. This is configured in SPRO under
  • Production Planning for Process Industries > Master Data > Master Recipe > Settings for the Task List Type > Define Profiles with Default Values.
  • Control Key (YBP4): The control key assigned to an operation or phase determines its business function. For example, does it confirm activity? Is it relevant for costing? Is it an external process? These are defined in SPRO under
  • Production Planning for Process Industries > Master Data > Master Recipe > Data for Operations and Phases > Define Control Keys.
  • Usage (1 - Production) : The usage key determines where the recipe can be used (e.g., Production, Engineering, Universal). Configuring this ensures that only valid recipes are selected during production planning.

2.3. Practical Exercise & Test Plan: Creating a Master Recipe

  • Scenario: Our company, Pharma Solutions, produces a liquid pain reliever, PS-PAINKILLER-FG (Finished Good). We need to create the master recipe detailing its two-stage manufacturing process: Mixing and Bottling.

Part 1: Initial Creation

  1. Log In: Access the SAP Fiori launchpad as a Production Engineer - Process Manufacturing.
  2. Access the App: Open the Manage Master Recipes (F5426) app and click Create.
  3. Enter Initial Data:
    • Material: PS-PAINKILLER-FG.
    • Plant: 1010 (Our German production facility).
    • Profile: YPI1.
    • Press Enter.
  4. Set Up Header Data:
    • On the Recipe Header tab, make the following entries:
    • Usage: 1 (Production).
    • Status: 4 (Released-General).
    • Planner Group: Enter the responsible planning group, e.g., 001.

Part 2: Define Operations and Phases

  1. Add Operation 0010 (Mixing):
    • Go to the Operations tab.
    • Resource: RES-MIX-01 (Mixing Tank Resource).
    • Control Key: YBP4.
    • Description: Mixing Active Ingredients.
  2. Add Phase 0011 (Under Operation 0010):
    • On the next line, check the
  • Phase Indicator box.
    • Superior Operation: 0010.
    • Resource: RES-MIX-01.
    • Control Key: YBP4.
    • Description: Charge and Mix Powders.
    • Double-click this phase line to enter details.
  1. Enter Standard Values for Phase 0011:
    • Go to the Standard Values tab.
    • Machine: 30 MIN (30 minutes of machine time).
    • Labor: 15 MIN (15 minutes of labor time).
    • Click the Back button to return to the operations overview.
  2. Add Operation 0020 (Bottling):
    • Go back to the Operations tab.
    • Resource: RES-BOT-01 (Bottling Line Resource).
    • Control Key: YBP4.
    • Description: Fill and Cap Bottles.

Part 3: Assign Material Components

  1. Select Materials Tab: Navigate to the Materials sub-tab.
  2. Insert Production Version: A dialog box will appear.
    • Production Version: Enter a new version code, e.g., 0001.
    • Alternative BOM: 1.
    • BOM Usage: 1 (Production).
    • Click
  • Check to validate, then Close Screen and Adopt Changes.
    • The components from your BOM (e.g., PS-ACTIVE-INGRED, PS-LIQUID-BASE, PS-BOTTLE) will now appear.
  1. Assign Components to Phases:
    • Select the material PS-ACTIVE-INGRED.
    • Click
  • New assignment.
    • In the dialog box, select the phase
  • 0011 (Charge and Mix Powders) and press Enter.
    • Repeat this for PS-LIQUID-BASE, assigning it also to phase 0011.
    • Assign the PS-BOTTLE component to operation 0020.
  1. Save the Recipe: Click the Save button. You will receive a message confirming the Master Recipe was created.

Test Execution & Expected Results:

  • Test 1 (Planning): A Production Planner runs MRP or manually creates a Process Order for PS-PAINKILLER-FG.
  • Expected Result 1: The system should automatically find and select the Master Recipe we just created. The resulting process order should contain the two operations (Mixing, Bottling) and the material components assigned to the correct steps.
  • Test 2 (Costing): A Cost Accountant runs a Product Cost Estimate for PS-PAINKILLER-FG.
  • Expected Result 2: The costing run should pick up the standard values (machine and labor times from the recipe phases) and material quantities (from the BOM assignments) to correctly calculate the standard cost of the product.

Chapter 3: Creating Packaging Material Master (3Y1)

  • Packaging is a crucial element in logistics. It protects products, facilitates handling, and impacts shipping costs and warehouse space. In SAP, packaging materials (like boxes, pallets, or containers) are a special type of product master with unique attributes.

3.1. Core Concepts: What is a Packaging Material?

  • A Packaging Material is a product master record with a specific material type, typically
  • VERP (Packaging), which enables specialized functions. Creating this master data correctly is vital because it directly influences:
  • Handling Unit Management (HUM) / Warehouse Management (EWM): How products are packed into larger units (Handling Units or HUs) for storage and movement.
  • Sales & Distribution (SD): How shipping weights and volumes are calculated for deliveries.
  • Logistics Execution (LE): Proper packing instructions and documentation.
  • Key fields unique to packaging materials include Packaging Mat. Type, Allowed pkg weight, and Handling Unit Type.

3.2. Prerequisites & Configuration Insights

Required Roles and Access:

  • Business Role: Master Data Specialist - Product Data (ID: SAP_BR_PRODMASTER_SPECIALIST).
  • System Access: SAP Fiori Launchpad.

Configuration Deep Dive (For Consultants & Key Users):

  • App/Transaction: The process can be done via the Fiori App Manage Product Master Data (F1602) or the traditional GUI transaction Create Material (MM01). The steps below will follow the MM01 app as it clearly separates the views.
  • Material Type (VERP): The material type VERP is the standard for packaging. In SPRO (
  • Logistics - General > Material Master > Basic Settings > Material Types > Define Attributes of Material Types), this type is configured with specific views enabled (e.g., Sales: General/Plant) and a unique item category group (VERP) assigned, which drives its behavior in sales documents.
  • General Item Category Group (VERP): This setting, entered in the Basic Data 1 view, is critical. It determines how the material is treated in sales and delivery processes, ensuring it's recognized as a packaging item.
  • Packaging Material Type: This field on the Sales: General/Plant view is configured in SPRO (Logistics - General > Handling Unit Management > Basics > Define Packaging Material Types). It groups packaging materials (e.g., all cardboard boxes, all pallets) and controls packing behaviors, such as weight and volume capacity.

3.3. Practical Exercise & Test Plan: Creating a Packaging Material

  • Scenario: Global Electronics needs to create a new master data record for the standard cardboard box they use to ship their 24-inch monitors.

Part 1: Create Basic and Sales Views

  1. Log In: Access the SAP Fiori launchpad as a Master Data Specialist - Product Data.
  2. Access the App: Open the Create Material (MM01) app.
  3. Enter Initial Data:
    • Material: PACK-BOX-L (for large packing box). You can also leave this blank for internal number assignment.
    • Industry Sector: M (Mechanical engineering).
    • Material Type: VERP (Packaging).
    • Click Select View(s).
  4. Select Views: In the pop-up, select the following views:
    • Basic Data 1
    • Basic Data 2
    • Sales: General/Plant Data
    • Click Continue (Enter).
  5. Define Organizational Levels:
    • Plant: 1710.
    • Sales Org: 1710.
    • Distr. Channel: 10.
    • Click Continue (Enter).
  6. Fill in Basic Data 1:
    • Description: Large Shipping Box - Monitors.
    • Base Unit of Measure: EA (Each).
    • Material Group: Select an appropriate group, e.g., for packaging materials.
    • General Item Category Group: VERP (This is crucial!).
    • Gross Weight: 0.5 KG.
    • Net Weight: 0.5 KG.
    • Volume: Enter the volume and unit.
  7. Fill in Sales: General/Plant Data:
    • Press Enter to navigate through Basic Data 2 to the Sales: General/Plant view.
    • Transp. Grp: 0001 (On pallets).
    • In the "Packaging material data" section:
      • Packaging Mat. Type: Select a type, e.g., 0001 (Cartons).
      • Allowed pkg weight: 20 KG (The maximum weight this box can hold).
  8. Save the Material: Click Save. The system will confirm that the material has been created.

Part 2: Extend for Warehouse Management (WM/EWM View)

  • For the box to be used in an EWM-managed warehouse, we need to add warehouse-specific data.
  1. Access the App: Open Change Material (MM02) or search for the product in Manage Product Master Data (F1602) and choose Edit.
  2. Enter Material: Enter PACK-BOX-L and click Select View(s).
  3. Select Views: Choose the following views:
    • WM Packaging
    • WM Execution
    • Click Continue (Enter).
  4. Enter WM Data:
    • Handling Unit Type: Enter the appropriate HU Type for a box, e.g., SP1. This is critical for EWM processes.
  5. Save Changes: Click Save.

Test Execution & Expected Results:

  • Test 1 (Sales): A Sales user creates a delivery for a TG-MONITOR-25. In the delivery document (VL02N), they go to the packing screen.
  • Expected Result 1: The user should be able to enter PACK-BOX-L as the packaging material. When they pack the monitor into the box, the system should correctly calculate the total gross weight of the Handling Unit (Box Weight + Monitor Weight). If they try to pack items exceeding 20 KG, the system should issue a warning or error.
  • Test 2 (Warehouse): In an EWM system, a warehouse operator is creating a packed Handling Unit at a work center.
  • Expected Result 2: When they specify PACK-BOX-L as the packaging material, the system automatically determines the Handling Unit Type as SP1, driving the correct follow-on processes and printing the correct HU labels.

Chapter 4: Creating Subscription & Configurable Service Products (5BD, 5BE)

  • The modern economy is increasingly service- and subscription-based. SAP S/4HANA provides robust tools to manage these complex products, from cloud storage subscriptions to configurable maintenance contracts. This chapter covers the creation of two key product types: the Subscription Product and the Configurable Service Product.

4.1. Core Concepts: Subscription vs. Configurable Products

  • Subscription Product (Scope Item 5BD): This represents a service sold on a recurring basis. The master data is typically created first in
  • SAP Subscription Billing and then replicated to S/4HANA. It consists of multiple components called "Rate Elements" which define the pricing structure (e.g., a one-time setup fee, a recurring monthly fee, and a usage-based fee).
    • Product Type in S/4HANA: SBPD (Subscription Billing Product).
    • Rate Element Type in S/4HANA: SBRE (Subscription Billing Rate Element).
  • Configurable Service Product (Scope Item 5BE): This is a service product where the customer can choose from various options, each potentially affecting the price. Think of a car wash service with options for 'Basic', 'Standard', or 'Premium' washes, with an optional 'Extra Polish'. This uses
  • Advanced Variant Configuration (AVC).
    • Key Components:
      • Characteristics: The features the customer can choose (e.g., SERVICE_CHANNEL with values 'Email' and 'Telephone').
      • Class: A container (Class Type 300) that groups the characteristics together.
      • Configuration Profile: Links the product to the class and defines the configuration behavior.
      • Variant Conditions: Special pricing records that add surcharges or discounts based on the chosen options.

4.2. Prerequisites & Configuration Insights

Required Roles and Access:

  • For Subscriptions (5BD):
    • Access to the
  • SAP Subscription Billing system.
    • In S/4HANA:
  • Master Data Specialist - Product Data (SAP_BR_PRODMASTER_SPECIALIST).
  • For Configurable Products (5BE):
    • Product Configuration Modeler (SAP_BR_PRODUCT_CONFIG_MODELER) to create characteristics and classes.
    • Master Data Specialist - Product Data (SAP_BR_PRODMASTER_SPECIALIST) to create the service product itself.
    • Pricing Specialist (SAP_BR_PRICING_SPECIALIST) to set variant prices.

Configuration Deep Dive (For Consultants & Key Users):

  • Subscription (5BD) Replication: A key setup step is configuring the integration flow (iFlow) between SAP Subscription Billing and SAP S/4HANA to ensure products and rate elements created in the billing system are automatically replicated to S/4HANA.
  • Configurable (5BE) Material Type: A mandatory preliminary step is to enable classification for the SERV material type. This is done by a configuration expert (
  • SAP_BR_BPC_EXPERT) in the Manage Your Solution Fiori app (or SPRO). This step adds the "Classification" tab to the material master, which is essential for assigning the configuration class.
  • Variant Configuration Table SDCOM: The VARKOND characteristic must reference table SDCOM and field VKOND. This is a standard SAP structure that links the characteristic values from the configuration to the variant condition records in pricing.
  • Item Category Groups: The choice of item category group (SCNP for service contract products, SRVP for service order products) is critical as it determines how the item behaves in sales documents and what pricing procedures are applied.

4.3. Practical Exercise & Test Plan: Creating a Configurable Service Product

  • Scenario: Global Electronics wants to offer a configurable maintenance plan for its corporate customers called "Premium Tech Support". Customers should be able to choose the support channel and the frequency of preventive maintenance.

Part 1: Create Characteristics and Class (Role: Product Configuration Modeler)

  1. Log In: Access Fiori as a Product Configuration Modeler.
  2. Create Characteristic 1 - VARKOND:
    • App:
  • Manage Characteristics.
    • Characteristic: VARKOND.
    • Description: Variant Condition Key.
    • Data Type: Character Format, Number of Chars: 26, Multiple Values: Selected.
    • On the
  • Addnl Data tab: Table Name: SDCOM, Field Name: VKOND, select Not Ready for Input and No Display.
    • Save.
  1. Create Characteristic 2 - GE_SUPPORT_CHANNEL:
    • App:
  • Manage Characteristics.
    • Characteristic: GE_SUPPORT_CHANNEL.
    • Description: Support Channel.
    • Data Type: Character Format, Number of Chars: 20, Multiple Values: Selected, Entry Required: Selected.
    • On the
  • Values tab, add: EMAIL / E-mail Support and TELEPHONE / Telephone Support.
    • Save.
  1. Create Characteristic 3 - GE_PREV_MAINT:
    • App:
  • Manage Characteristics.
    • Characteristic: GE_PREV_MAINT.
    • Description: Preventive Maintenance Frequency.
    • Data Type: Character Format, Number of Chars: 20, Multiple Values: Selected, Entry Required: Selected.
    • On the
  • Values tab, add: YEARLY / Yearly, HALFYEARLY / Half-Yearly, QUARTERLY / Quarterly.
    • Save.
  1. Create the Class:
    • App:
  • Manage Classes.
    • Class: GE_SERVICE_CONTRACT_C.
    • Class Type: 300 (Variants).
    • Description: Global Electronics Service Contract Class.
    • On the
  • Char. tab, assign all three characteristics created above: VARKOND, GE_SUPPORT_CHANNEL, GE_PREV_MAINT.
    • Save.

Part 2: Create the Service Product (Role: Master Data Specialist)

  1. Log In: Access Fiori as a Master Data Specialist - Product Data.
  2. Create Material: App: Create Material (MM01).
    • Material: SRV_CONTR_CONFIG_GE
    • Material Type: SERV (Service Product).
  3. Select Views & Org Levels: Select Basic Data 1, Sales views, and Classification. Use Plant/Sales Org/Distr. Channel
  • 1710/1710/10.
  1. Enter Data:
    • Basic Data 1:
      • Description: Premium Tech Support Plan.
      • Base Unit of Measure: AU (Activity Unit).
      • GenItemGroup: SCNP (Serv. Contract Prod.).
      • Check the
  • Material is configurable box.
    • Sales Views: Set Tax classification to 1 (Full tax).
    • Classification View:
      • Assign the class
  • GE_SERVICE_CONTRACT_C.
      • Save the material.

Part 3: Create Configuration Profile & Set Prices (Roles: Config Modeler & Pricing Specialist)

  1. Create Configuration Profile (Config Modeler):
    • App:
  • VC Modeling Environment.
    • Enter material
  • SRV_CONTR_CONFIG_GE and create a configuration profile for it.
    • On the
  • Variant Pricing tab, assign variant condition keys to your characteristic values (e.g., Value EMAIL gets Variant Cond. EMAIL; Value YEARLY gets YEARLY).
  • Save.
  1. Set Prices (Pricing Specialist):
    • App:
  • Set Material Prices.
    • Set Base Price: Create a condition record for type PSI1 for material SRV_CONTR_CONFIG_GE. Amount:
  • 200.00 USD. This is the base price of the contract.
    • Set Variant Prices: Create condition records for type VASE (Variant Price). Enter the variant condition keys you defined in the profile and give them a surcharge:
      • EMAIL: 30 USD
      • TELEPHONE: 50 USD
      • YEARLY: 250 USD
      • HALFYEARLY: 135 USD
      • QUARTERLY: 90 USD
    • Save all records.

Test Execution & Expected Results:

  • Test: A Sales user creates a Service Contract (VA41) for a customer and enters the material SRV_CONTR_CONFIG_GE.
  • Expected Result: A configuration screen should pop up. The user must select a support channel and a maintenance frequency. Based on their selections, the price in the service contract should be calculated automatically. For example, selecting "Telephone Support" and "Yearly" maintenance should result in a total price of 200 (base) + 50 (telephone) + 250 (yearly) = 500 USD.

Chapter 5: Creating a Functional Location (5LM)

  • In Plant Maintenance (PM), it's crucial to structure your technical assets logically. A
  • Functional Location is a hierarchical organizational unit that represents a location where a maintenance task is performed. It could be a physical place (e.g., Pump Station 1) or a logical system (e.g., Hydraulic System).

5.1. Core Concepts: What is a Functional Location?

  • Functional Locations are the backbone of your plant's technical structure. They allow you to:
  • Structure assets hierarchically: You can build a multi-level structure, from a whole building down to a specific assembly line, and then to a motor on that line.
  • Track maintenance history: All maintenance orders, notifications, and costs can be recorded against a functional location, providing a complete history for that area or system over time.
  • Analyze costs: Aggregate maintenance costs at any level of the hierarchy.
  • Manage equipment: Equipment (individual, physical objects) can be installed at functional locations.

5.2. Prerequisites & Configuration Insights

Required Roles and Access:

  • Business Role: Maintenance Planner (ID: SAP_BR_MAINTENANCE_PLANNER).
  • System Access: SAP Fiori Launchpad.

Configuration Deep Dive (For Consultants & Key Users):

  • App/Transaction: The primary Fiori App is Create Technical Object. The equivalent GUI transactions are
  • IL01 (Create) / IL02 (Change).
  • Structure Indicator (YBPM) : This is a critical configuration setting that defines the format of the functional location ID, including the number of hierarchy levels and the characters used at each level. For example, a structure could be defined as
  • XXXX-XXX-XXX, allowing for a 3-level hierarchy. This is configured in SPRO: Plant Maintenance and Customer Service > Master Data in Plant Maintenance and Customer Service > Technical Objects > Functional Locations > Create Structure Indicator for Reference Locations/Functional Locations.
  • Technical Object Category (M) : This key specifies the type of functional location, with 'M' being the standard for technical systems. It controls which fields are available and how the object behaves.

5.3. Practical Exercise & Test Plan: Building a Functional Location Structure

  • Scenario: Global Electronics wants to structure its main production building (Plant 1710). We will create a top-level location for the building and then subordinate locations for the two main assembly lines within it.
  1. Log In: Access Fiori as a Maintenance Planner.
  2. Access the App: Open the Create Technical Object app.
  3. Create Top-Level Functional Location (The Building):
    • Select
  • Technical Object Type: Functional Location.
    • Structure Indicator: YBPM.
    • Technical Object: GE-1710 (Global Electronics Plant 1710).
    • Technical Object Category: M.
    • Click Continue.
  1. Maintain Data for GE-1710:
    • General Data:
      • Description: Production Building - Plant 1710.
    • Location Data:
      • Maintenance Plant: 1710.
    • Organizational Data:
      • Cost Center: Enter the cost center for the building, e.g., 17101701.
      • Planning Plant: 1710.
      • Maintenance Work Center: Enter the main maintenance team, e.g., RES-0100.
    • Click Save. A confirmation message appears.
  2. Create Subordinate Location 1 (Assembly Line 1):
    • Repeat steps 2 & 3, but this time for
  • Technical Object: GE-1710-ASL01.
    • The system automatically recognizes that this is a subordinate location based on the structure indicator.
    • Description: Assembly Line 01 - Monitors.
    • Fill in the Location and Organizational data as you did for the parent, or use more specific data if applicable (e.g., a different work center for this line).
    • Click
  • Save.
  1. Create Subordinate Location 2 (Assembly Line 2):
    • Repeat the process for
  • Technical Object: GE-1710-ASL02.
    • Description: Assembly Line 02 - PCs.
    • Save.

Test Execution & Expected Results:

  • Test 1 (View Hierarchy): Open the Display Technical Object app or Asset Viewer. Enter the top-level location
  • GE-1710 and view its structure.
  • Expected Result 1: The system should display a tree structure with GE-1710 at the top, and GE-1710-ASL01 and GE-1710-ASL02 as child nodes underneath it.
  • Test 2 (Create Notification): A maintenance technician creates a maintenance notification using the Create Maintenance Notification app. When specifying the technical object, they search for functional locations in Plant 1710.
  • Expected Result 2: The search results should allow the user to see and select any of the three functional locations we created. If they create a notification for a problem on Assembly Line 1, they should assign it to GE-1710-ASL01. Later, a maintenance planner can run reports for all notifications related to the entire building (GE-1710) and see this notification included.
